name: Hamiltonian decomposition
rephrased: For certain graphs, it is possible to divide all the edges into sets, each forming a single cycle that visits every vertex exactly once (a Hamiltonian cycle).
implication_form: If a graph has a Hamiltonian decomposition, then its edges can be partitioned into Hamiltonian cycles.
posed_by: Attributed to Hamiltonian cycle concepts (named after William Rowan Hamilton), but no specific proposer for the decomposition conjecture is widely recognized.
explained: A Hamiltonian decomposition refers to a specific concept in graph theory, not an open conjecture. It describes a partition of the edges of a graph (either undirected or directed) into Hamiltonian cycles. In the undirected case, this is equivalent to a 2-factorization (a decomposition into disjoint cycles covering all edges) where each factor (cycle) is connected. There is no specific mathematical statement (like 'the graph has a Hamiltonian decomposition') that is being conjectured here; the definition itself is the key point.
related_conjectures: Hamiltonian Cycle Problem (a central NP-complete problem in graph theory)
Tait's conjecture (about Hamiltonian cycles in cubic graphs)
